subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon, mixing well.
Pour the egg yolk and cheese mixture over the spaghetti and bacon, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.
If needed, add more reserved pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano or parmesan cheese and more black pepper before serving.

original_steps: Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcome: Egg yolks separated and placed in a bowl
Grated pecorino romano cheese mixed with egg yolks
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl. Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Egg yolks are used in carbonara to create a creamy sauce. Pecorino Romano cheese adds flavor to the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick or the back and forth method to separate the yolks. If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcome: Bacon is cooked until crispy and cooled slightly.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooling the bacon slightly prevents overcooking the egg-based sauce when it is added later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Wait until there's no sizzle left and a bit longer to ensure the bacon is not too hot.

metadata.title: Not Spaghetti Carbonara - You Suck at Cooking (episode 138)

subtitles.text: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.
It's so simple!
Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.
Let's not waste any time, now let's go!
Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.
So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon.
And thick cut bacon would be best.
You could also use pancetta.
So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.
That's about three quarters of an inch.
Turn this pan on to medium heat.
I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right.
Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan.
And what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy.
We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?
Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese.
Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.
I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano.
That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff.

So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding.
I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description.
Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up.
So here's all our beautiful cheese.
Okay, now time for the eggs.
A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks.
I like to do a mixture of both.
So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.
The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks.
Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture.
And you'll see all that, and it looked like so much cheese, right?
But as this breaks down, it won't look like that anymore.
Add that all in.
And so now we have a consistency like this.
Now, this is a very important time for our good friend, Sergeant Gilbert.
I'm gonna put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture.
If you didn't know already, Gilbert is just fresh ground black pepper.
He's a sentient being, a pepper grinder, who became selfaware in 2020.
You know, and this is preference.
Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.
As you can see, there's a lot of fat coming out of this bacon.
Just want to turn this occasionally.
And we are going to be using some, but not all of this fat in the actual spaghetti carbonara.
Another thing you can do is just take a little bit of that boiling water and add it to the eggs.
Quickly whisk that in.
We're kind of equalizing the temperatures here and loosening up this egg mixture a little bit, and it's going to make the whole pasta come together a lot easier in the end.
I put just about a quarter cup in here.
Our bacon is almost rendered, so now we'll drop our spaghetti.
We'll try to do that twisty thing.
Kind of worked.
Just get a little bit of water up on it.
Let that roll.
Check it on the bacon.
I turned the heat down in the end.
Be careful not to overcook this.
Looks pretty much perfect.
First, I'm going to take some out for garnish.
Drain it on a paper towel.
Now I'm turning off the heat of this pan, and I'm going to drain off most of the fat, all except for about two tablespoons or so.
And then just set that back over there.
Remember, now, heat is off.
This is so important.
Okay, and of course, we're going to put some olive oil in this pasta.
No, we're not going to do that.
Why do people do that?
It's a myth.
It's a myth.
Just like MSG is going to give you cancer or whatever.
It's just not true, and it serves no purpose.
So don't do it.
Don't do it, okay?
Another thing I want to share with you, there are tons of expensive pasta brands out in the world, but honestly, like, I like these cheap Italian brands, like this one, Giacchecco.
I don't know how to say it, but like, I don't know why.
I just prefer the cheap one.
So if anyone's wondering, this is what I use.
So we'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente, and then we'll finish it over in this baking pan.
Remember, still no heat on this pan.
I'm going to explain all this soon, but you want to leave this water in this pot.
This will make sense in a minute.
So here we go.
It's been 10 minutes.
We're just going to use our tongs here.
Drop that in there.
Trust me, this spaghetti is generating a ridiculous amount of heat.
Turn that pasta water down to a simmer.
Once you have all the pasta out, now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.
The whole trick here, and what you really need to keep in mind is that we do not want to scramble these eggs.
The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?
And don't worry, you're not eating raw eggs.
And gentle with the pasta.
You don't want to break it.
Oh, man.
And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.
You see how creamy this is?
I'm also using these La Crusade pans, which I'll link in the description, and they hold a lot of heat.
So I don't think I even need to do my plan, but I can show you why I left that pasta water on.
Because if it doesn't thicken up like you like, literally what you can do is set that pan back on top of that pasta water and like a double boil or bainmarie, it will keep cooking the egg mixture.
But I don't think I even really need to do this.
But that's a good option, especially if you're using a pan that's not as thick as this.
Oh, my God.
Looks so good.
And if it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water.
That's going to loosen it up.
And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.
Done.
No scramble, nothing.
Go ahead and plate this up.
Just get it off the tongs like so.
Oh, man.
Now to finish a little more pan migliano reggiano.
All over, nothing wrong with that.
And of course, some of your crispy bacon.
Just for an added crunch.
That is a bonus no one is going to complain about.
Trust me. I mean, how bad do you want to tuck into this treat?
Allow me to try it.
Oh, allow me to try it for you.
Here we go.
A little bacon.
Oh, gosh.
I see a lot of people who leave my YouTube videos right now.
It's such a big mistake.
They obviously don't know about the fridge.
Oh, God, that's good.
You've got to make this.
Here's my rolling pin.
I just feel like this is what an Italian grandmother would do.
Whew.
What?
Well, I hope that helped.
Until next time, my friends, you know I love you when I'm out.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some pieces for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Reserve some pasta water and drain the spaghetti.
Add the spaghetti to the pan with the bacon fat (heat still off).
Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon pieces.

subgoals.text: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it. It's so simple! Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right. Let's not waste any time, now let's go! Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured. So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon. And thick cut bacon would be best. You could also use pancetta.

subgoals.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
subgoals.text: So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way. That's about three quarters of an inch.
original_steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.

subgoals.title: Cook Bacon-2
subgoals.text: Turn this pan on to medium heat. I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right. Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan. And what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy. We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?
original_steps: Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.

subgoals.title: Cook Pasta-3
subgoals.text: Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water. Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
original_steps: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.

subgoals.title: Prepare Ingredients-4
subgoals.text: So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese. Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged. I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano. That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff. So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding. I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description. Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up. So here's all our beautiful cheese. Okay, now time for the eggs. A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks. I like to do a mixture of both. So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks. The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks. Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture. And you'll see all that, and it looked like so much cheese, right? But as this breaks down, it won't look like that anymore. Add that all in. And so now we have a consistency like this.
original_steps: Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.

subgoals.title: Mix Egg and Cheese-5
subgoals.text: Now, this is a very important time for our good friend, Sergeant Gilbert. I'm gonna put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture. If you didn't know already, Gilbert is just fresh ground black pepper. He's a sentient being, a pepper grinder, who became selfaware in 2020. You know, and this is preference. Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.
original_steps: Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.

subgoals.text: As you can see, there's a lot of fat coming out of this bacon. Just want to turn this occasionally. And we are going to be using some, but not all of this fat in the actual spaghetti carbonara. Another thing you can do is just take a little bit of that boiling water and add it to the eggs. Quickly whisk that in. We're kind of equalizing the temperatures here and loosening up this egg mixture a little bit, and it's going to make the whole pasta come together a lot easier in the end. subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
materials: Half a pound of thick-cut bacon
outcome: Bacon cut into three-quarter inch pieces
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The bacon is cut into pieces to be cooked and rendered for use in the pasta and as garnish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Thick-cut bacon is preferred for better texture and flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcome: Bacon is crispy and fat is rendered out
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Rendering out the fat from the bacon and making it crispy is essential for flavor and texture in the pasta carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Turn the bacon occasionally to ensure even cooking and prevent burning.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
outcome: Pasta water is seasoned with salt
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because carbonara contains many salty elements.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Usually, more salt is added to pasta water, but for carbonara, less is used due to the other salty ingredients.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcome: Grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese. In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The mixture of eggs and cheese will create a creamy sauce for the pasta without using cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a fine setting on a cheese grater for the cheese. Adjust the amount of cheese and eggs based on personal preference for richness.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix Egg and Cheese-5
outcome: Egg and cheese mixture seasoned with black pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste and whisk it in.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The amount of black pepper added is based on personal preference.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use as much or as little black pepper as you like based on your taste preference.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcome: Bacon pieces are set aside for garnish
Most of the bacon fat is drained, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the bacon is crispy, remove some pieces for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: This step is important to ensure that the bacon fat does not overpower the dish and to prepare the pan for the next steps without burning the ingredients.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Use a paper towel to drain the bacon pieces for garnish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
outcome: Spaghetti is drained and some pasta water is reserved.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the spaghetti is cooked for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente, use tongs to remove the spaghetti from the pot, leaving the pasta water in the pot. Turn the pasta water down to a simmer.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The reserved pasta water can be used to adjust the consistency of the sauce later, making it creamier if needed.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti; it should be slightly al dente. Use tongs to handle the spaghetti gently to avoid breaking it.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-8
outcome: The egg and cheese mixture coats the spaghetti in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the hot spaghetti and stir gently.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the pasta will cook the eggs gently, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be gentle with the pasta to avoid breaking it and ensure the eggs do not scramble.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-9
outcome: Achieve a creamy consistency for the pasta sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: If needed, add reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding pasta water helps to loosen the sauce and establish a creamy texture without using cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce looks too thick, adding pasta water can help loosen it up.

metadata.title: Pasta Carbonara the American Way (With Bacon)

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop bacon, separate egg yolks, and grate cheese.
original_steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Cook bacon until crispy and let it cool.
original_steps: Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some pieces for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Mix Egg and Cheese
subgoal_definitions.description: Combine egg yolks, cheese, and pepper.
original_steps: Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil spaghetti until al dente and reserve pasta water.
original_steps: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water and drain the spaghetti.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix pasta with bacon and egg mixture to create sauce.
original_steps: Add the spaghetti to the pan with the bacon fat (heat still off).
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon, mixing well.
Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Pour the egg yolk and cheese mixture over the spaghetti and bacon, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.

subgoal_definitions.title: Finish and Serve
subgoal_definitions.description: Adjust sauce consistency and garnish before serving.
original_steps: If needed, add reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
If needed, add more reserved pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon pieces.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano or parmesan cheese and more black pepper before serving.
